title: Tesla to open extensive charging network to GM's electric vehicles
description: General Motors and Tesla CEOs made the announcement on Thursday, June 8, 2023, during a Twitter Spaces conversation. GM joins Ford in pushing to make Tesla's connectors the industry standard.

title: Supreme Court rules in favor of Black Alabama voters in unexpected defense of Voting Rights Act
description: Two conservative American justices joined liberals in rejecting a Republican-led effort to weaken landmark Black voting rights on Thursday, June 8th, in a congressional redistricting case from Alabama.

title: Annecy knife attack: What we know about stabbing of four children and two adults
description: The suspect is a Syrian national who had lived in Sweden for 10 years, where he was recently granted refugee status.

title: Southern Ukraine's agriculture threatened again by Kakhovka dam destruction
description: Cereal and sunflower oil production could be affected for many years to come. After falling for several weeks, world wheat prices surged in response.

title: France adopts its first heat wave management plan
description: The frequency of extreme weather events in France is set to double by 2050, and the government needs to consider structural solutions to deal with them.

title: French Open: Unseeded Muchova achieves dramatic comeback to overpower No. 2 Sabalenka to reach finals
description: Karolina Muchova will now face either No. 1 Iga Swiatek or No. 14 Beatriz Haddad Maia in her first Grand Slam final on Saturday.

title: Ukraine: For now, there is enough water to cool Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant
description: The level of Ukraine's Kakhovka reservoir, which has been dropping since the dam was destroyed earlier this week, could soon be too low to supply the power plant. Authorities have alternatives for the time being.

title: Jane Fonda and French junior minister for seas: 'We must accelerate our fight for the ocean'
description: On the occasion of World Oceans Day on June 8, the American actress/climate activist and Hervé Berville call for the ratification of the Global Ocean Treaty and for a total ban on deep-sea mining.

title: 'CNN and the decline of an American icon'
description: The channel founded in 1980 revolutionized television by inventing rolling news coverage. Chris Licht's departure, after just 13 months in charge, reveals its current difficulties, writes columnist Philippe Escande.

title: French Open: The workers who get their hands dirty with clay to keep the tennis going
description: Almost 200 people from various backgrounds are employed on a temporary basis to maintain the courts at Roland-Garros during the Grand Slam tournament.

title: Lebanon recalls ambassador to France after rape accusations
description: Lebanon's foreign ministry announced it was bringing back Rami Adwan  after an investigation was opened into allegations of rape and intentional violence by him.

title: France lags far behind on recycling targets, warns European Commission
description: While the European goal is to recycle 50% of plastic packaging by 2025, France is stagnating at under 27% and is proving to be incapable of reducing its household waste.

title: What we know about the Annecy knife attacker
description: Details are gradually emerging about the man who stabbed six people, including four very young children, beside a popular lake in the French Alps.

title: Russia's Belgorod region is increasingly drawn into the war in Ukraine
description: Targeted by repeated sabotage and armed raids, the oblast bordering Ukraine is suffering the aftermath of the 'special operation' launched a year and a half ago by Vladimir Putin.

title: San Francisco in the time of 'Fentalife'
description: The capital of tech has become the capital of fentanyl, a synthetic opioid 50 times stronger than heroin, available in doses costing less than $10. The city center has been drained of its tech workers and stores are closing.

title: 'China and the United States: Yin and yang'
description: Beijing and Washington nurture an ambiguous relationship, combining close economic ties with open political and military hostility, writes Le Monde columnist Alain Frachon.

title: Knife attacker injures several people, including children, in French Alpine city
description: A man was arrested. Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne announced she is traveling to the scene in Annecy.

title: French pension reform opponents push for unlikely repeal bill
description: Legislators from the centrist opposition group LIOT proposed a text to return the retirement age in France to 62 after the recent reform raised it to 64.

title: Naples in Paris: 'We're lending 70 works to the Louvre,' says Museo di Capodimonte director
description: The Neapolitan institution will be closed for two years for renovations. In an interview with Le Monde, the Naples museum's director Sylvain Bellenger explains the process of ^rep the Paris exhibition.

title: Ukraine: Fears of environmental disaster after Kakhovka dam destruction
description: The dam's destruction has been described as 'the worst environmental disaster in Europe since Chernobyl' by Ukraine's deputy foreign minister. Its impact is expected to be considerable on ecosystems.

title: Kakhovka dam breach: Flooding extends over 600 square kilometers, residents evacuated
description: The state emergency service of Ukraine said 1,995 people had been evacuated from flooded areas, including 103 children. Many more have fled of their own accord.

title: Post Brexit, the UK's agriculture sector is in crisis
description: Farmers are going out of business, breeders are selling off their herds and there are food shortages in stores. The end of EU subsidies and soaring energy costs are putting a strain on the agricultural model across the Channel.

title: NBA Finals: Nuggets beat Heat in Miami to take a 2-1 series lead
description: Nikola Jokic and Jamal Murray each recorded triple-doubles in a 109-94 win in game three on Wednesday.

title: 'Le Pen's strength lies in being faced with opponents who accuse each other of being responsible for her rise'
description: As political parties from all sides look to counter the far-right Rassemblement National, infighting among them is hindering their efforts, writes Le Monde columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: Prime Minister Borne's chief of staff will quit in July
description: Aurélien Rousseau had said he would leave his position once the pension reform was completed. The prospect of negotiating with the right-wing opposition on the future immigration law convinced him to step down.

title: Vietnam battles record heat waves and power cuts
description: Record-breaking temperatures in mainland Southeast Asia in April and May were accompanied in Vietnam by a sharp rise in electricity consumption, which the country's major cities are trying to contain.

title: 'The Russian army is influenced by beliefs that detach them from objective reality'
description: According to researcher Dimitri Minic, the failure of the Russian army in Ukraine is the result of the implementation of a theory that emerged in the 2000s, which places a central focus on 'psychological-informational' warfare rather than armed combat.
